document.docTitle: A new species of Pseudorientalia (Gastropoda: Hydrobiidae) from midwestern Türkiye with notes on Pseudorientalia natolica (Küster, 1853)

emphasis.docTitle:
A new species of
Pseudorientalia
( Gastropoda : Hydrobiidae ) from midwestern Türkiye with notes on
Pseudorientalia natolica (Küster, 1853)

subSection.paragraph: DENIZ ANIL ODABAŞI 1, 3,* , DENIZ MERCAN 2, 4 , SERPIL ODABAŞI 1, 5 & NAIME ARSLAN 2, 6

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Çanakkale Onsekiz Mart University, Department of Marine and Inland Water Sciences, Faculty of Marine Science and Technology, T ¸rkiye
Eskişehir Osmangazi University, Faculty of Science, Department of Biology, Türkiye

subSection.paragraph:
The members of the genus
Pseudorientalia Radoman, 1983
are small hydrobiid species with characteristic features of the penis and female genitalia. The type locality of the genus is the southern Marmara region, northwestern T ̧rkiye. In this study, sampling was carried out in the upper Sakarya River Basin, western-middle Anatolia to obtain hydrobiid specimens, which yielded a new
Pseudorientalia
. The shell, penis, and female genitalia of the new species are described. The measurement of some shell characters is compared with the other representatives of the genus from T ̧rkiye, northern Greece , and some Aegean islands: Samos, Chios and Lesvos. In addition, notes on
Pseudorientalia natolica
are also given from examination of the type specimens.
Key words: Mollusca , endemic , freshwater , protected wetland

Pseudorientalia Radoman, 1983
is a small freshwater snail, up to 2 mm long, with an oval, conical shell and a pointed spire ( Radoman, 1983 ). Ķster (1852) was the first to describe this genus as
Paludina natolica
from northwestern Türkiye (Pınarbaşı Suyu, Gedelek-Bursa). Radoman (1983) revised this genus as
Pseudorientalia
, based on individuals from the type locality. In T ̧rkiye, some samples have been attributed to
Pseudorientalia natolica
from several sources away from the type locality, including Inkaya village ( Bursa ), a spring in Çay district ( Afyonkarahisar ) and a spring near Aksu district ( Kahramanmaraş ) ( Radoman 1983 ; Schütt 1965).

To date, two species have been designated in the genus
Pseudorientalia
,
P. natolica
(Ķster, 1852), the type species of the genus, and
P. ceriti
Ģrlek, 2017, described from southeastern T ̧rkiye.
Szarowska et al. (2014a
; b) discovered several populations of
Pseudorientalia
from the Greek islands of Samos, Chios and Lesvos in the Aegean Sea, which were distinguished from each other on the basis of morphological and genetic data.
Pseudorientalia tzekovi Glöer and Gerogiev, 2012
was later placed in the genus
Turkorentalia ( Glöer 2022 )
.

In the present study, a new
Pseudorientalia species
was found in the Göksu Stream, which flows through the protected area of the Balıkdamı Wetland, a tributary of the Sakarya River in northwestern Türkiye . In addition to shell morphology, the penis and female reproductive organs of the sampled individuals were examined and found to be significantly different from other conspecifics and identified as a new species. This study also provides detailed notes on the shell, penis and female genitalia of topotypic individuals of
Pseudorientalia natolica
(Ķster, 1853), the type species of this genus.

The field study was conducted on the two main springs of the Balıkdamı Wetland, an upper tributary in the Sakarya River Basin, West Central Anatolia-Türkiye ( Fig. 1 ). Balıkdamı is one of the wetlands in the Sakarya River Basin (Magnin et al . 1997: 670); the floodplain has a variety of microhabitats such as marshes and reed beds, which are fed by groundwater springs. Sampling was carried out at two groundwater sources on 9 May 2023 using a D-Frame hand net and a 500 µ mesh sieve. The benthic material was sieved, and the gastropods were transferred to 50 mL plastic tubes containing 96% alcohol.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1 . The sampling sites. Yellow rectangle: The geographical position of the study area, Yellow Star: Type locality of
Pseudorientalia natolica , Blue Star
: Type locality of
Pseudorientalia ceriti , Red
dots: Sampling sites, 1: Type locality of the new species, 2: Spring from which additional material was obtained. (Map scale, Türkiye; 1:7.300.000, the study area; 1:55.900, EsriSat).

subSection.paragraph:
In the laboratory, shell measurements and dissections of soft body parts of
Pseudorientalia
sp. n.
were performed under a stereo microscope and digital imaging system (Stemi 508, Zeiss and Axiocam 105 color) in Çanakkale Onsekiz Mart University. Ten shell characters were measured, namely shell height (SH), shell width (SW), body whorl width (BWW), body whorl height (BWH), aperture height (AH), aperture width (AW), spire height (SpH), whorl number (WN), apex angle (α), the angle between the body whorl suture and the horizontal surface (β) ( Fig. 2 ). Two morphometric indices, SW/SH and AH/SH, were also calculated using Excel (MS Office). Prior to applying the student-t test to the data, a normality test was conducted. A Shapiro-Wilk normality test found that most parameters did not conform to a normal distribution (p<0.05). Therefore, the data was subjected to log transformation using IBM SPSS Statistics 21.0. After applying log transformation, the data was tested for normality again. It was found that most of the data followed a normal distribution. However, WN, ALPHA, and BETA did not fit the normal distribution and were therefore excluded from the t-test comparisons for
P. natolica
and
P. kanari
sp. n.
.

The type material of
Pseudorientalia natolica (Küster, 1853)
in the personal collection of D.A. Odabaşı was used in the re-description and comparison with the new species.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype :
Alcohol-fixed specimen from Göksu Spring, 39°09’01.5”N 31°36’49.2”E ,
839 m
. alt., Göktepe village , Sivrihisar district , southeast of Eskişehir province , Türkiye ( Fig. 1 : 1, Fig. 4 ) leg. Naime Arslan and Deniz Mercan on
9 th of May 2023
, deposited at the Limnology Museum of Çanakkale Onsekiz Mart University ( COMULM ) under the voucher code of COMULM-G 298 . Shell Height = 2.4 mm , SW = 1.42 mm , AH = 1.06 mm , AW = 0.86 mm , ( Fig. 3A ).

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 2 . Shell morphometric parameters displayed on the shell. AH: aperture height, AW: Aperture width, BWH: Body whorl height, BWW: Body whorl width, SH: Shell height, SpH: Spire height, SW: Shell width, α: Apex angle, β: Angle between the body whorl suture and the horizontal surface.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Paratypes :
Twenty fully grown, alcohol-fixed specimens leg. Naime Arslan and Deniz Mercan from type locality on
9 th of May 2023
, were measured. Five of which were dissected and deposited in COMULM and Eskişehir Osmangazi University, Museum of Hydrobiology Department, ( ESOGU ), Ţrkiye under the codes of COMULM-G 299 (15 specimens including soft parts) and
ESOGU Gastropoda (C) No 2
( 5 specimens) ( Fig. 3. B–I )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Pseudorientalia kanari
sp. n. A.
shell of the holotype, B–I. paratypes: ( B-C ) shells from station 2; ( D ) penis in situ (sta-2); ( E ) penis in situ (type loc.); ( F ) operculum from type loc.; ( G ) penis close-up (sta-2); ( H ) penis close-up (type loc.); ( I ) female genitalia (type loc.). Scale bars: A–C = 1 mm, D–I = 0.5 mm. bc: Bursa copulatrix, e: Eye Spot, f: Foot, p: Penis, ro: Renal oviduct, rs: Seminal receptacle, s: Snout, t: Tentacle.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Additional Materials: Four specimens were measured, two of which were dissected from the 2 nd station ( Fig. 1 : 2); Karkolu Spring 39°09’10.6”N 31°37’00.4”E ,
806 m .
alt., leg. Deniz Mercan and Naime Arslan, 9 th of May 2023 . Deposited in COMULM-G 300.
Etymology. The species is named after Mehmet Sait Kanar, head of the Eskişehir Nature Conservation and National Parks Department.

Description: Shell conical, semi-transparent with glossy or rough surface up to 4½ slightly convex and regularly growing whorls. Sutures shallow, umbilicus open, continuous aperture ovoid and angled at top, operculum concentric and yellowish in color. Mantle dark black. Face with black patches, tentacles white with black stripe around eyes. Penis simple, elongated, awl-like, black pigmented from its middle to the tip, vas deferens invisible. Female reproductive organs unpigmented, with two seminal receptacles (rs), rs-1 very fine, rs-2 thick thread-shaped. Renal oviduct looped. Medium-sized bursa copulatrix circular shaped and depressed at both sides of the center ( Fig. 3. A–I ).

Habitat: The type locality is a spring with several outflows in the area. The fast-flowing water is crystalline and the bottom covered with cobble – pebble substrate with patches of filamentous algae ( Fig. 4 ). The only species found with
Pseudorientalia kanari
sp. n.
is
Theodoxus sp.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4. The type locality of
Pseudorientalia kanari
sp. n.
Göksu Spring, Göktepe village, Sivrihisar district, southeast of Eskişehir province, Türkiye.

TABLE 1. Biometry of some shell characters of
Pseudorientalia kanari
sp. n.
in millimeters: M: Mean, Min.: Minimum value, Max.: Maximum value, n: Number of individuals, SE: Standard error, AH: Aperture height, AW: Aperture width, BWH: Body whorl height, BWW: Body whorl width, SH: Shell height, SpH: Spire height, SW: Shell width, SW/SH: Ratio of shell width to shell height, α: Apex angle, β: Angle between the body whorl suture and the horizontal surface.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Differential diagnosis:
Pseudorientalia kanari
sp. n.
is clearly distinct from
P. natolica
by its shell and anatomical features:
P. kanari
sp. n.
has up to 4½ slightly convex whorls with open sutures, high spire and open umbilicus, whereas
P. natolica
has 3½–4 tumid whorls with well-developed last whorl.
Pseudorientalia natolica
has lower spire and deeper sutures than those of
P. kanari
n. sp.
and has a slit-like umbilicus, unlike
P. natolica
. The biometry of the shell characters differed significantly from each other according to Student-t test. In this context, all of the measured shell parameters with normal distribution were significant at the p<0.001 except BWH. In the penis and female genital comparisons, we found minor differences between penes of
P. kanari
sp. n.
and
P. natolica
: The penis is simple and elongated with black pigmentation from the middle to the tip in
P. kanari
sp. n.
, whereas in
P. natolica
the penis is awl-like with a broader base and pigmented in the middle. There are, however, clear differences in the genital chambers of the females of these two species: The bursa copulatrix (bc) is quite large and rs-2 short but stubby in
P. natolica
, whereas
P. kanari
sp. n.
has a medium sized bc that is depressed on both sides and rs-2 like a thickened thread. Facial pigmentation is characteristic of both species, e.g. the head and tentacles of
P. natolica
are dark black, whereas the black face with black stripes is visible around the eyes of the tentacles of
P. kanari
sp. n.

Also found in Ţrkiye is
Pseudorientalia ceriti
from south-eastern Anatolia ; quite far from the type locality of
Pseudorientalia kanari
sp. n.
Although the number of whorls in both species above are up to 4½,
P. ceriti
has smaller shell dimensions than those of
P. kanari
sp. n.
The maximum values of SH, SW, AH and AW of
P. ceriti
were 1.83, 1.2, 0.96 and 0.78 mm respectively, smaller than
P. kanari
sp. n.
( Table 1 ). Furthermore,
P. ceriti
has a darker snout and lighter tentacles than
P. kanari
sp. n.
( Fig. 3 : D-E; Gürlek 2017: 995). The unnamed populations of the genus
Pseudorientalia
in the Aegean Islands differed from each other based on morphological and genetic data (
Szarowska et al. 2014a
; b). They are also separated by their morphological structures from the Turkish conspecific taxa, as well as
P. kanari
described here.

The following notes on
P. natolica
based on topotype specimens. The shell measurements, penis and female genitalia of the samples were investigated.

Topotype specimens:
Twenty seven shells of
P. natolica
from type locality, leg. Deniz Anıl Odabaşı on 22 nd of
May 2021
deposited in COMULM (G–251), were measured and 5 of them were cracked to reveal of the soft parts’ morphology including penis and female genitalia. Some of the mean values of shell morphometry as follows: SH = 1.6 mm , SW = 1.28 mm , AH = 0.89 mm , AW = 0.79 mm , BWH = 1.28 mm , BWW = 1.04 mm ( Table 2 )
.

caption.paragraph:
TABLE 2. Biometry of some shell characters of
Pseudorientalia natolica
(in millimeters, n= 27). M: mean, Min.: minimum value, Max.: maximum value, n: number of individuals, SE: standard error AH: Aperture height, AW: Aperture width, BWH: Body whorl height, BWW: Body whorl width, SH: Shell height, SpH: Spire height, SW: Shell width, SW/SH: Ratio of shell width to shell height, α: Apex angle, β: Angle between the body whorl suture and the horizontal surface.

FIGURE 5.
Pseudorientalia natolica
. A. Shell, B. Penis in situ , C. Operculum, D–E. Penis close-up, F. Female genitalia. Scale bars: A = 1 mm, B–F = 0.5 mm. ac: Alimentary canal, bc: Bursa copulatrix, e: Eye spot, f: Foot, p: Penis, ro: Renal oviduct, rs: Seminal receptacles, s: Snout, t: Tentacle.

subSection.paragraph:
The description of
P. natolica
given by Radoman (1983: 85–86) in general may be applied to the topotypes described in the present study. However, the conchological parameters are slightly different, e.g. SH, SW, AH, and AW in the original description were 1.97–2.18, 1.30–1.47, 0.92–1.09, and 0.88–1.01, respectively, while in this study they were 1.34–1.82, 1.18–1.46, 0.81–1.03, and 0.71–0.85 ( Table 2 ). Our data show that the topotype population of
P. natolica
has smaller shell dimensions than reported in the species’ description. The
Pseudorientalia
populations from Samos, Chios, and Lesvos islands are distinct from each other according to genetic and morphological data (
Szarowska et al . 2014b
) and are also morphologically distinct from
P . kanari
sp. n.
and
P. natolica
. Collecting genetic data will provide information that will shed light on the divergence of these species.

This study was supported by the revolving fund budget of Eskişehir Nature Conservation and National Parks Section Directorate under the title “Activity 1.5.1. Monitoring of priority invertebrate animal species for conservation” which is included in the management plan of Balıkdamı Wetland, a wetland of national importance, for the years 2019–2023.
